item.title: The Weekly Challenge - Guest Contributions
item.description: As you know, The Weekly Challenge, primarily focus on Perl and Raku. During the Week #018, we received solutions to The Weekly Challenge - 018 by Orestis Zekai in Python. It was pleasant surprise to receive solutions in something other than Perl and Raku. Ever since regular team members also started contributing in other languages like Ada, APL, Awk, BASIC, Bash, Bc, Befunge-93, Bourne Shell, BQN, Brainfuck, C3, C, CESIL, Chef, COBOL, Coconut, C Shell, C++, Clojure, Crystal, D, Dart, Dc, Elixir, Elm, Emacs Lisp, Erlang, Excel VBA, F#, Factor, Fennel, Fish, Forth, Fortran, Gembase, Gleam, GNAT, Go, GP, Groovy, Haskell, Haxe, HTML, Hy, Idris, IO, J, Janet, Java, JavaScript, Julia, K, Kap, Korn Shell, Kotlin, Lisp, Logo, Lua, M4, Maxima, Miranda, Modula 3, MMIX, Mumps, Myrddin, Nelua, Nim, Nix, Node.js, Nuweb, Oberon, Octave, OCaml, Odin, Ook, Pascal, PHP, PicoLisp, Python, PostgreSQL, Postscript, PowerShell, Prolog, R, Racket, Rexx, Ring, Roc, Ruby, Rust, Scala, Scheme, Sed, Smalltalk, SQL, Standard ML, SVG, Swift, Tcl, TypeScript, Typst, Uiua, V, Visual BASIC, WebAssembly, Wolfram, XSLT, YaBasic and Zig.

item.title: Caching using Memcached
item.description: Recently I shared my experience with Redis/Valkey. Continuing my exploration, today I’d like to talk about another very popular choice Memcached.

item.title: CVE-2025-40909
item.description: In this post, we demonstrate how to reproduce CVE-2025-40909, a vulnerability in Perl related to working directories and thread behaviour.

item.title: Caching in Perl
item.description: Caching is the process of storing frequently accessed or computed data in a temporary, high-speed storage layer.

item.title: Serialisation in Perl
item.description: Serialisation is the process of converting complex Perl data structures (hashes, arrays, objects) into a format that can be stored or transmitted and later reconstructed.

item.title: AWS Lambda
item.description: This post comes nearly a month and a half after the last one. The previous post on an AWS related topic was about AWS DynamoDB. The break wasn’t intentional, though.
